Line 13: Line 13:  
The above conception is diametrically opposed to the conception of [[capitalism]], which promotes the so called inherent [[selfishness]] of the human being, and on which it's supported.<ref>TR Machan. ''Selfishness and capitalism''. 1974.</ref> [[Gilles Deleuze]] and [[Félix Guattari]] consider that capitalism produces a perversion of the natural concept of love, by placing the human being as a part of a production machine, and thus destructing the concepts of body and soul.<ref name="Deleuze">Gilles Deleuze. Félix Guattari. ''[http://books.google.es/books?id=FQe7w8psqfQC&printsec=frontcover&source=gbs_ge_summary_r&cad=0#v=onepage&q&f=false El anti Edipo]''. 1972, 1985. ISBN 978-84-7509-329-1.</ref> [[Ayn Rand]], on the other side, states that selfishness is in essence a noble feeling (one should be responsible for his own happiness, and not others').<ref>[http://marsexxx.com/ycnex/Ayn_Rand-The_Virtue_of_Selfishness.pdf Ayn Rand. ''The virtue of selfishness''.]</ref>
 
The above conception is diametrically opposed to the conception of [[capitalism]], which promotes the so called inherent [[selfishness]] of the human being, and on which it's supported.<ref>TR Machan. ''Selfishness and capitalism''. 1974.</ref> [[Gilles Deleuze]] and [[Félix Guattari]] consider that capitalism produces a perversion of the natural concept of love, by placing the human being as a part of a production machine, and thus destructing the concepts of body and soul.<ref name="Deleuze">Gilles Deleuze. Félix Guattari. ''[http://books.google.es/books?id=FQe7w8psqfQC&printsec=frontcover&source=gbs_ge_summary_r&cad=0#v=onepage&q&f=false El anti Edipo]''. 1972, 1985. ISBN 978-84-7509-329-1.</ref> [[Ayn Rand]], on the other side, states that selfishness is in essence a noble feeling (one should be responsible for his own happiness, and not others').<ref>[http://marsexxx.com/ycnex/Ayn_Rand-The_Virtue_of_Selfishness.pdf Ayn Rand. ''The virtue of selfishness''.]</ref>
    −
[[Humanistic psychology]] sets healthy [[self-esteem]] as an essential requirement for every healthy interpersonal relationship, including interpersonal love.<ref>Nathaniel Branden. ''The psychology of self-esteem: a new concept of man's psychological nature''. 1981.</ref> [[Nathaniel Branden]] stresses the importance to be aware of the difference between healthy self-esteem and [[narcissism]],<ref>Nathaniel Branden. ''The psychology of self-esteem: a new concept of man's psychological nature''. 1981.</ref> this latter understood as self-indulgence and self-aggrandizement, and characteristic of an unhealthy self-esteem.
+
[[Humanistic psychology]] sets healthy [[self-esteem]] as an essential requirement for every healthy interpersonal relationship, including interpersonal love.<ref> [[Abraham Maslow]] places love at the ''love/belonging level'', between the ''safety level'' and the ''esteem level'', in his [[Maslow's hierarchy of needs|hierarchy of needs]].
     
<!-- themes -->Love in its various forms acts as a major facilitator of [[interpersonal relationship]]s and, owing to its central psychological importance, is one of the most common themes in the [[creative arts]].
